learning.explanation: INERTIAL NAVIGATION SYSTEM (INS) vs. INERTIAL REFERENCE SYSTEM An Inertial Reference System (IRS) is a more modern and advanced version of the traditional inertial navigation system (INS) used in aviation. The main difference between the two systems is that an IRS uses solid-state sensors, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and gyroscopes, instead of traditional mechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers. Some of the main advantages of the more modern IRS are: - The solid-state sensors are more reliable and require less maintenance compared to mechanical gyroscopes. They also provide higher accuracy and faster response times, resulting in more precise and smoother navigation - The IRS can be integrated with other navigation systems, such as GPS or ground-based radio beacons, to provide even more accurate and reliable navigation information. - IRS systems also have the ability to compensate for various types of errors that may affect the accuracy of the navigation data. For example, errors caused by temperature changes, sensor drift, or other external factors. While traditional INS systems using mechanical gyroscopes and stand-alone computers are still in use in many aircraft today, IRS systems offer several advantages over their predecessors, including higher accuracy, faster response times, and better reliability.

The general principle of an inertia navigation system (INS) is that the system measures the aircraft's accelerations from a known position and speed, then integrates those accelerations to calculate speed and therefore distance travelled in each axis (North/South and East/West) to constantly determine its up-to-date position. The components of an INS are 1. Accelerometers 2. Gyroscopes 3. Position computer A "stable platform INS" is made in such a way that the 3 rate-integrating gyroscopes measure any rotations of the aircraft and immediately apply a current to a motor to oppose this motion, thereby keeping the platform in the same orientation it was set to (horizontal and North facing). learning.explanation: The ring laser gyro (RLG) is a modern, more sophisticated alternative to the conventional gyroscope. It is used for the aircraft inertial navigation systems and attitude/heading reference systems. It is a very accurate system to measure rotation about a given axis and is widespread in modern commercial aircraft IRS systems. Conventional gyro’s rotation mass is replaced by two contra-rotating beams of light. The case of the RLG is made of a vitreous ceramic material of low-temperature coefficient. Two gas-tight openings are carefully designed into the single-piece case of the RLG, which are then filled with inert gas, such as a mixture of Helium and Neon. A direct current electrical discharge ionizes the gas and creates two beams of light flowing in opposite directions in the two cavities of the RLG case. In order to produce a continuous laser circuit in the enclosed area of the RLG’s case, a set of mirrors is installed to reflect and trap the laser beams. The frequency of oscillation of each beam depends on the optical path length and corresponds to the cavity resonance condition. When the RLG is stationary, both optical path lengths of each beam are identical. However, when the RLG is rotated about the axis perpendicular to the laser beams plane, one beam will travel a larger distance, and the other will cover a shorter distance. The frequency difference induced by different path lengths is proportional to the rotation rate.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Navigation System is a self-contained system that can provide continuous information on the aircraft's position, track, heading, groundspeed and, if necessary, height without any external assistance. Most aircraft of any size will be fitted with at least two inertial systems. The duplication is for redundancy and so that the information can be compared for possible error. The starting point for an inertial navigation system is acceleration. If acceleration is known, then the aircraft's speed can be calculated. If the speed is known, the distance travelled can be calculated. To solve a complete navigation problem in space, we need to know the acceleration in three axes at right angles to each other. The inertial system relates its acceleration to the three axes and recognizes the direction, using three methods: Stable Platform or Stabilised Inertial Platform Wander Angle Strapdown The Stable Platform, which keeps the platform, on which the accelerometers are mounted, always level and aligned to North, and also measures acceleration relative to the platform. Alignment and levelling is done only once for each flight with the aircraft stationary on the ground. Once aligned, the inertial system is not and cannot be re-aligned for the remainder of the flight. Attitude data is still valid, and will continue to drive servo attitude and heading instruments or EFIS indications.

key_points: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration
This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night
The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. The quality of information is dependent on the accuracy of the initial (input) data, and the precision with which the system aligns to True North. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. To keep the reference valid, the accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Rate integrating gyros are for use as sensors to detect any departure of the platform from its level and desired alignment. BOUNDED ERRORS These errors build up to a maximum positive and negative values, and return to zero within each 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle and thus averages out over the period. The main causes of these errors are: - platform tilt, due to initial misalignment - inaccurate measurement of acceleration by accelerometers - integrator errors in the first integration stage UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE TRACK ERRORS These errors arise from the misalignment of the accelerometers in the horizontal plane, and the main causes of these errors are: - Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. - Wander of the azimuth gyro. UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE DISTANCE ERROR These errors give rise to cumulative errors in the recording of the total distance travelled. The main causes of this error are: - Wander in the levelling gyros. - Integrator errors in the second stage of integration. INHERENT ERRORS The irregular shape and composition of the Earth, together with the movement of the Earth through space, and other factors provide further possible sources of error. Such errors vary from system to system, depending upon the balance achieved between accuracy on one hand and the simplicity of design, reliability, ease of construction and cost of production on the other.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) receives data from three internal Ring Laser gyros (RLGs), and three internal accelerometers, measuring accelerations on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). Other data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position at any point during the flight, is calculated from the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – to stabilize the vertical navigation, thus stabilizing vertical velocity and inertial altitude information. The platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

content.question: An inertial navigation system includes in its composition three linear accelerometers, in order to measure the…

options.A: true airspeed (TAS) on the x, y and z axes.
options.B: indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes.
options.C: acceleration along the aircraft's pitch, roll and yaw axes.
options.D: acceleration along the North-South, East-West and vertical axes.

key_points: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking
If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft
learning.explanation: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking. If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft. The basic principle is that, if an INS knows the initial location of the aircraft, and knows that it is completely still at that time (during initialisation), then it can precisely measure the aircraft's turns and accelerations to calculate its current position. It uses the mathematical process of integration to first work out the aircraft's velocity and direction, then integrates again to find the change in distance, which it then adds/removes from the original location. The oldest INSs use a "stable platform" design, which is a large platform that is kept pointing towards True North and perfectly upright, no matter the aircraft's heading or attitude. It manages this by using 3 rate-integrating gyros to measure the aircraft's turns around all three axes, and counter them by moving the platform the other way. It can then use 2 accelerometers to calculate the North-South acceleration, and the East-West accelerations, which are fed into a mechanical computer (a complex set of cogs and gears) that provide an output of speed and position, and other useful metrics. More modern aircraft use Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs), which are a form of INS, but are connected directly to the aircraft (no stable platform). These are much lighter, and less complex to have on board, as they use a set of 3 ring laser gyroscopes and 3 accelerometers to measure all the rotations and accelerations, and then calculates into their various components (North-South, East-West and Vertical) using modern computer methods. This is called a strapdown system, as it is fixed to the aircraft, and is much more usable with other systems, as it can feed info to the FMS, etc. This question is not very well worded, as the question is asking about inertial navigation systems, but the most correct answer (and the answer from feedback) is actually more related to IRSs. To clarify, we can go through each option: "true airspeed (TAS) on the x, y and z axes." This is quite blatantly wrong, airspeed is measured in one axis by the pitot tubes. "indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes." Same as above, still wrong. "acceleration along the aircraft's pitch, roll and yaw axes." This one is nearly correct, as it does sense accelerations, but not necessarily along these axes (and these axes refer to rotations). INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions (and maybe vertically). "acceleration along the north-south, east-west and vertical axes." This is most correct, but only just. As mentioned above, INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions. They can sense vertical accelerations also, if they have a third accelerometer, but this is not so well documented in the learning objectives, and is more to do with IRSs, which all measure vertical acceleration as part of their normal process. This is why this question can garner some opposing views, depending on interpretation. So far, this is our best option.

content.question: Which statement is true about the navigational database of a FMS?

key_points: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage
The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc
they might need along their route
learning.explanation: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage. The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc. they might need along their route. An example of an additional waypoint could be some Decision Points, which coordinates are indicated in the Operational Flight Plan the crew receives during the briefing. On a several sectors day, it is very common that the pilot stores the flight back (the second sector) on this additional storage of the navigation database. For instance, the FMS2 Honeywell Release 1A, allows the flight crew to create and store up to 99 waypoints, 10 runways, 20 navaids, and 5 routes. This will be different from one FMS to another, but it already gives you an idea of the capability of the additional storage space of the navigation database, called the supplemental navigation database. Caution! It is really important to understand and make the difference that pilots can use the Supplemental Navigation database to write and read information => by adding their own customized waypoint or other navigation data. BUT this is limited to ONLY this Supplemental Nav database! At the time of the Main Nav database update (every 28 days) the Supp Nav database is automatically erased. It makes sense as the Supp Nav database could include waypoints that have been defined using waypoints contained in the Main Nav database that may have changed as a result of the update.

learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called its database. The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model. The data stored in the database includes aircraft drag and engine characteristics, maximum and minimum speeds. Generally, in the cockpit preparation phase and before starting to program the FMGS, the pilots will check both databases: - The performance database is checked by confirming the engine and aircraft type as well as the performance factor. - The navigation database validity is checked by confirming the current day is within the validity interval. If any of these databases are wrong (wrong engine/aircraft or validity expired) an authorised mechanic has to change it to the correct one.

key_points: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory
The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing several extremely useful functions
One of those functions is the aid for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance
learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing several extremely useful functions. One of those functions is the aid for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance. This function will basically make internal calculations based on the aircraft weight, its cruising level, and the actual and expected wind conditions en-route to estimate the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan. Most of the time this tool is very accurate, but the number of parameters influencing the fuel consumption makes it difficult to exactly predict the fuel consumption. That’s why you always need to do fuel checks at regular intervals during the flight and check that the fuel consumption is normal, the remaining fuel to destination is still the same, and there’s no leak. The FMS has also the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions.

learning.explanation: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary loadable components for the FMC to be operative. The performance data base includes aircraft’s drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path. The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow. The navigation data base of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav data base is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

In any case, if you go off your flight plan route, the FMS will display you the XTK on the ND
learning.explanation: The FMS cross-track (XTK) error is the abeam distance error, either side of the desired flight plan leg. In any case, if you go off your flight plan route, the FMS will display you the XTK on the ND. options.C: navigation database in the FMC is valid for one year.

key_points: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link
These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC)

The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link. These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. The second is the model and engine performance database and contains all the aircraft performance data which allows the FMC to compute fuel burn, optimum altitudes and airspeeds, etc. The third is the Navigation Database (NDB). The NDB is contains all the information required for building a flight plan and processing that plan when airborne. All these databases are stored in the FMC on an electrically erasable programmable read-only memory (EEPROM) card. Each of these databases can be updated via a data loader every 28 days. AIRAC updated every 28 days contains read only data but the pilot is still able to enter fixes, phantom stations and adjust parameters according to how he needs it within certain limits The NDB contains terminal and en route fixes; waypoints and navigation reference system (NRS) grid points; intersections; airways and radio navigation aids. It also contains airports; runways; STAR and SID; holding patterns; and instrument approaches such as VOR, non-directional beacon, area navigation (RNAV), required navigation performance (RNP), satellite based navigation system (SBAS), and ground based navigation system (GBAS).

content.question: After an approach at your destination, the weather is found to be below limits, and you decide to divert to your alternate aerodrome. options.D: Use both the FMS time and fuel predictions.

key_points: The fuel prediction logic of the FMS is predicated on the aircraft being in what is considered to be the “normal” configuration for the phase of flight

learning.explanation: The fuel prediction logic of the FMS is predicated on the aircraft being in what is considered to be the “normal” configuration for the phase of flight. However, under circumstances of Abnormal Aircraft Configuration, such as slats not retracting, the fuel predictions are no longer accurate. Failure to realize this situation has lead crews to make false assumptions about their range and endurance and has been a contributory cause factor in several accidents and incidents. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. content.question: For polar navigation, aircraft manufacturers recommend navigation using...

options.A: LNAV to follow rhumb line
options.B: HDG to follow great circle
options.C: HDG to follow rhumb line
options.D: LNAV to follow great circle

key_points: POLAR NAVIGATION In the polar region, magnetic heading is unreliable or totally useless for navigation
Magnetic variations typically are extreme, often are not constant at the same point, and change rapidly as an airplane changes position
Flight crews must ensure that the computer flight plan shows true tracks and headings
learning.explanation: POLAR NAVIGATION In the polar region, magnetic heading is unreliable or totally useless for navigation. Magnetic variations typically are extreme, often are not constant at the same point, and change rapidly as an airplane changes position. Flight crews must ensure that the computer flight plan shows true tracks and headings. If an active route takes an airplane over a pole, the preferred mode is lateral navigation (LNAV) with the autopilot engaged. The flight management system (FMS) of some modern large transport jets (such as the B747 or B777) are operational in the polar areas with no restrictions. LNAV guidance outputs from the FMC are normally great circle courses between the waypoints that make up the active route.

content.question: What can be expected when there's a complete loss of GPS signal?

options.A: Loss of radio navigation signals.
options.B: Loss of integrity monitoring (RAIM) and RNP APCH capability.
options.C: Position uncertainty due to ND units shutdown.
options.D: Calculated position deviation.

key_points: GPS POSITION The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position
Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position
For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data
learning.explanation: GPS POSITION The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position. Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position. For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data. If the GPIRS data does not comply with an integrity criterion that is based on a Horizontal Integrity Limit (HIL) and on the automatic detection of failed satellites, the FMS rejects the GPS mode and uses the radio position update. The flight crew can deselect/select the GPS position on the SELECTED NAVAIDS page, if necessary. Without GPS PRIMARY (GPS deselected or inoperative) the navigation accuracy is lower and is a function of ground radio navaid infrastructure or elapsed time since the last radio update. RNAV(GNSS) approaches may be performed, provided GPS PRIMARY is available and with AP or FD engaged. The flight crew may check the position computation using the POSITION MONITOR page. RAIM Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitor (RAIM) is a form of integrity monitoring performed within the avionics themselves. It ensures available satellite signals meet the integrity requirements for a given phase of flight. By comparing the distance measurements of a number of satellites, the RAIM function can identify a satellite failure and issue an alert to the pilot. Without RAIM capability, the pilot has no assurance of the accuracy of the GPS position. A minimum of five satellites is required to detect a bad satellite; at least six satellites are required to detect and exclude a bad satellite from the navigation solution if your receiver has a fault detection and exclusion (FDE) RAIM algorithm.

content.question:
Which of the following are part of an FMS CDU (Control Display Unit)?
1. Printer
2. Display
3. Line select keys
4. Circuit breaker
5. Function and execute keys.
6. Alphanumeric and miscellaneous keys

key_points: The Command Display Unit (CDU), as is the means by which the flight crew can communicate with the computer
An alpha/numeric CRT screen dominates the upper part of the unit, while the lower part has a keyboard
Using the keyboard, the flight crew can enter the desired vertical and lateral flight plan data into the Flight Management Computer
learning.explanation: The Command Display Unit (CDU), as is the means by which the flight crew can communicate with the computer. An alpha/numeric CRT screen dominates the upper part of the unit, while the lower part has a keyboard. Using the keyboard, the flight crew can enter the desired vertical and lateral flight plan data into the Flight Management Computer. The parts of the CDU and their individual functions are as follows: A — Line Select Keys: (Six each side of screen) Push to select or enter data on the adjacent line. B — CDU Display: Displays the page of data selected by function, mode, or Line Select key. C — Page Title: Indicates the type of data displayed. When in lateral or vertical navigation modes, displays ACT or MOD, indicating the page status. D — Page Number: The first digit represents the page number and the second digit indicates the total number of related pages. E — Boxes: Indicates the data required by the FMC for full navigation capability. Data is entered from the scratch pad, using the Line Select key. F — Dashes: Indicate that a data entry is required by the system. If known, key in and transfer the data from the scratch pad using the appropriate Line Select key. G — Line Title: Indicates the type of data on the line. This is blank if data is not recognised by the FMC. H — Scratch Pad Line: This is the bottom line of the display and displays: - System generated messages to the flight crew - All keyboard entries (before transferring to the required line) - Data moved from one line to the other I - Display Brightness adjuster J - Execute: This refers to making entered data part of the active flight plan by pushing the illuminated EXEC key.

content.question: While preparing the FMGS for the first flight of the day, the pilots notice that the navigation database is out of date. What should they do?

options.A: Select the valid database.
options.B: Download the up to date database via ACARS and select it.
options.C: Download a valid database from EFB and select it.
options.D: Use the current database.

key_points: The information stored in the FMC is called its data base
The data base is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation
The FMGC navigation data base includes most information that would normally be determined by referring to navigation charts
learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called its data base. The data base is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The FMGC navigation data base includes most information that would normally be determined by referring to navigation charts. The stored information includes the location of navigation aids, airports, runways and other airline selected information such as SIDs, STARs, approaches and company routes. The FMGC contains two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each set corresponds to the normal revision cycle for navigation charts. During preflight the flight crew can select which set is active. Cycling the database erases the primary and secondary flight plans, as well as stored data. The flight crew must never do this in flight. The contents of the navigation data base are updated by maintenance every 28 days.

content.question:
With regard to a dual Flight Management System (FMS), which statement is correct?
FMC = Flight Management Computer

options.A: In `Dual Mode` both FMCs independently process the pilots` inputs, there is zero cross-checking between the FMCs.
options.B: Both FMS independently process the respective pilot’s inputs in “dual mode”, and cross-checking between them does not occur.
options.C: In `Single Mode` both FMCs are decoupled, and there is zero cross-checking between them.
options.D: In `Independent Mode` both FMCs are decoupled, and there is zero cross-checking between them.

key_points: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus
learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

content.question: May an FMS receive position inputs from the GPS system (if installed)?

options.A: Yes, but only for horizontal position data, not vertical position data.
options.B: No, GPS is considered too inaccurate and unsecure for this.
options.C: Yes, but only if a dual GPS system is installed.
options.D: Yes, this is common.

learning.explanation: 022.05.01.01.06: State that in modern aircraft fitted with inertial reference system (IRS) and flight management system (FMS), the flight management computer (FMC) position is normally derived from a mathematical analysis of IRS, global positioning system (GPS), and distance measuring equipment (DME) data, VHF omnidirectional radio range (VOR) and LOC. The FMS uses a position that is a combination of the IRS position, GPS position and radio position (auto-tuning ground nav-aids). The FMS selects the best-calculated position based on a figure of merit and priority, called a Kalman Filter. For instance, GPS is the most accurate indication of position, so is usually the main input, but when that is no longer accurate enough, the FMS has to use the IRS and radio position, also depending on their current availability. Of course, IRS position is the most available data, as it does not require external information, but radio position is often more accurate, when available. The FMC determines and updates present aircraft position from the following systems: Loran – C (LOC) DME IRS GPS

content.question: What effect could the loss of GPS signal have on the FMS?

options.A: The aircraft position could be different from what is calculated.
options.B: None as it uses radio aids for position, not GPS.
options.C: It will use the IRS position.
options.D: No effect.

key_points: The FMS uses a position that is a combination of the IRS position, GPS position and radio position (auto-tuning ground nav-aids)
The FMS selects the best-calculated position based on a figure of merit and priority, called a Kalman Filter

For instance, GPS is the most accurate indication of position, so is usually the main input, but when that is no longer accurate enough, the FMS has to use the IRS and radio position, also depending on their current availability
learning.explanation: The FMS uses a position that is a combination of the IRS position, GPS position and radio position (auto-tuning ground nav-aids). The FMS selects the best-calculated position based on a figure of merit and priority, called a Kalman Filter. For instance, GPS is the most accurate indication of position, so is usually the main input, but when that is no longer accurate enough, the FMS has to use the IRS and radio position, also depending on their current availability. Of course, IRS position is the most available data, as it does not require external information, but radio position is often more accurate, when available. Modern FMS systems are very clever, and can automatically deselect GPS inputs if they become erroneous or lose signal, however, this is detrimental to the accuracy of the system, and will then have to use less accurate position data. This means that the aircraft may have a different position to what is calculated by the FMS, due to this lack of accuracy. content.question: Sources of navigation data outputs of the FMC that are displayed on an EFIS are…

options.A: IRS, navigation radios, and TCAS.
options.B: GPS, AWR, and navigation radios.
options.C: IRS, AWR, and navigation radios.
options.D: Navigation radios, GPS, and IRS.

key_points: The question simply asks you what information from the provided elements will be displayed on your PFD and ND by the FMS
Obviously, the navaids (=navigation radios) will be displayed
You will be able to have them on the lowest part of your ND (identifier + distance from the station)
learning.explanation: The question simply asks you what information from the provided elements will be displayed on your PFD and ND by the FMS. Obviously, the navaids (=navigation radios) will be displayed. You will be able to have them on the lowest part of your ND (identifier + distance from the station). Additionally, the bearing needles could also be displayed. The navaids are automatically tuned from the received signal and the navigation database of the FMS. The FMS computed position along the flight plan is derived from the data provided by the IRS, DME, VOR, and the GPS. A monitoring section is provided in the MCDU where you can actually check the accuracy and integrity of the GPS signal and select the desired position computation method. The output of all this visible on the EFIS is the aircraft position along the flight plan route, its offset (when under radar vectoring), and any relative position from a navaid, airport, obstacle. The TCAS and AWR are standalone systems that are not interacting with the FMS. Therefore, the outputs displayed on the EFIS are not from the FMS.
